title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #7: Covering Systems with Odd Moduli**

Is there a covering system all of whose moduli are odd?

**Conjecture (Erdős-Selfridge)**: NO such system exists.

**Prizes**: $25 (Erdős) + $2000 (Selfridge for explicit construction)

**Partial Results**:
- Hough-Nielsen (2019): Some modulus divisible by 2 or 3
- Balister et al. (2022): No odd squarefree covering exists
mathContext: A covering system covers all integers via congruence classes. This problem asks whether the prime 2 is essential for covering systems.

title: Congruence Class
content:
**CongruenceClass** represents an arithmetic progression {residue + k*modulus : k ∈ ℤ}.

Requires modulus ≥ 2 to avoid trivial or empty progressions.
mathContext: Congruence classes partition integers by residue modulo m. The Chinese Remainder Theorem relates overlaps.

title: Class to Set
content:
**toSet** maps a congruence class to the set of integers {x : x ≡ residue (mod modulus)}.

Uses Int.ModEq for modular equivalence.
mathContext: This is the set-theoretic interpretation of a congruence class.

title: Covering System
content:
**CoveringSystem** is a list of congruence classes covering all integers.

Every integer belongs to at least one class: ∀ x, ∃ c ∈ classes, x ∈ c.toSet
mathContext: Covering systems are fundamental in number theory. The simplest is {0 mod 2, 1 mod 2}.

title: Erdős-Selfridge Conjecture (OPEN)
content:
**erdos_selfridge_conjecture**: ¬∃ cs : CoveringSystem, cs.allOddModuli

No covering system has all moduli odd. This is the main OPEN question.
mathContext: This would show the prime 2 is essential for covering all integers with congruence classes.

title: Equivalence of Formulations
content:
**erdos_selfridge_equiv**: erdos_selfridge_conjecture ↔ erdos_selfridge_alt

The two formulations are logically equivalent via negation and odd/even duality.
mathContext: Shows the conjecture can be stated positively (every covering has even modulus) or negatively (no all-odd covering exists).

title: Squarefree Moduli
content:
**Squarefree n**: No prime squared divides n.

**allOddSquarefreeModuli**: All moduli are both odd AND squarefree.

This is the case ruled out by Balister et al.
mathContext: Squarefree numbers have no repeated prime factors. Products of distinct primes.

title: Balister et al. (2022)
content:
**balister_odd_squarefree**:

¬∃ cs : CoveringSystem, cs.allOddSquarefreeModuli

No covering has all moduli both odd AND squarefree. Major breakthrough toward the conjecture.
mathContext: Balister, Bollobás, Morris, Sahasrabudhe, Tiba (2022) used probabilistic and combinatorial methods.

title: Hough-Nielsen (2019)
content:
**hough_nielsen**:

∀ cs : CoveringSystem, ∃ c ∈ cs.classes, DivisibleBy2Or3 c.modulus

Every covering has a modulus divisible by 2 or 3. Implies odd coverings need 3-divisible moduli.
mathContext: Hough and Nielsen (2019) used sieve methods to prove this restriction.

title: LCM Constraint
content:
**odd_covering_lcm_constraint**:

If an odd covering exists, its LCM must be divisible by 9 or by 15.

This constrains the prime factorization of any hypothetical odd covering.
mathContext: The LCM encodes the period of the covering. Divisibility by 9 or 15 comes from density arguments.

title: Combined Constraints
content:
**odd_covering_constraints**: If an odd covering exists, it must have:

1. Some modulus divisible by 3 (Hough-Nielsen)
2. LCM divisible by 9 or 15
3. Non-squarefree moduli (Balister et al.)

These severely restrict what an odd covering could look like.
mathContext: Combining all known constraints shows any odd covering must have very specific structure.

title: Selfridge's $2000 Challenge
content:
**selfridge_challenge**: Construct an explicit covering system with all moduli odd AND distinct.

Note: Non-constructive existence proofs would NOT collect this prize.
mathContext: Selfridge offered $2000 specifically for explicit construction, separate from Erdős's $25 for any proof.

title: Problem Summary
content:
**Erdős Problem #7: OPEN**

**Conjecture**: No odd covering system exists.

**Known**:
- Some modulus divisible by 2 or 3
- No odd squarefree covering
- LCM must have 9 or 15

**Prizes**: $25 + $2000
mathContext: The problem remains open despite significant partial progress. An odd covering would be highly structured if it exists.
